Classes¶

OpenKet classes¶

DiracObject¶

class DiracObject¶

A class for representing quantum objects, such as quantum operators and states.

The DiracObject class is the OpenKet representation of quantum operators and state vectors. This class also implements math operations +,-,* between DiracObject instances (and / by a complex number).

Ket¶

class Ket(a, A='default')¶

A class for representing a state, called ket. Ket is a class inheritanced from DiracObject.

Parameters:

  • a (int or Sympy variable) – Vector tag. Must be either a number class or a Sympy variable.

  • A (string, optional) – Operator tag. The ket is then the eigenvector of the operator, and they comply with the eigenvalues equation. Also this param could be the Hilbert space tag where the ket lives.

Examples¶

In this example x and v are two different objects. x is a Sympy variable and v is the object Ket.

>>> x = var("x")
>>> ket_x = Ket(x)
>>> ket_x
|x>

In the following example, although u and w have the same vector tag, they are not treated as the same object. For this kind of tags, strings as well as Sympy variables may be used.

>>> a = Ket(1,"A")
>>> b = Ket(1,"B")
>>> a.eig
1
>>> b.op
'B'

Bra¶

class Bra(a, A='default')¶

A class for representing the vectors corresponding to the dual space, called bras. Bra is a class inheritanced from DiracObject.

Parameters:

  • a (int or Sympy variable) – Vector dual tag. Must be either a number class or a Sympy variable.

  • A (string, optional) – Operator tag representing the eigenvalues equation for vector whose bra is the dual. Also this param could be the Hilbert space tag where the corresponding ket lives.

Example¶

In this example y and z are two different objects. y is a Sympy variable and z is the object Bra.

>>> y = var("y")
>>> bra_y = Bra(y)
>>> bra_y
<y|
>>> bra_y.eig
y
>>> bra_y.op
'default'

Operator¶

class Operator(A)¶

A class for representing an operator. Operator is a class inheritanced from DiracObject.

Parameters:

A (string) – Operator tag.

Example¶

The symbol on the left of the equality does not need to be the same as the argument of Operator, this is just how you are calling it, where as the argument is how OpenKet tags it.

>>> A = Operator("A");
>>> A
A
>>> name = Operator("up")
>>> name.op
'up'

It is convenient to have the same tags if no confusion is produced. However the option is always available to name objects the way we want.

CreationOperator¶

class CreationOperator(htag='default', maximum=0)¶

A class for representing the Creation operator.

\[\begin{split}\begin{aligned} \hat{a}^{\dagger}|n\rangle &= \sqrt{n+1}|n+1\rangle \\ \langle n| \hat{a}^{\dagger} &= \sqrt{n} \langle n-1| \\ \end{aligned}\end{split}\]
Parameters:

  • htag (string, optional) – Hilbert space tag.

  • maximum (int, optional) – Maximum value for n.

Example¶

>>> n = var("n")
>>> ket_n = Ket(n); bra_n = Bra(n)
>>> aa = CreationOperator()
>>> aa*ket_n
(1 + n)**(1/2)|n+1>
>>> bra_n*aa
n**(1/2)<n-1|

AnnihilationOperator¶

class AnnihilationOperator(htag='default', maximum=0)¶

A class for representing the Annihilation operator.

\[\begin{split}\begin{aligned} \hat{a}|n\rangle &= \sqrt{n}|n-1\rangle \\ \langle n| \hat{a} &= \sqrt{n+1} \langle n+1| \\ \end{aligned}\end{split}\]
Parameters:

  • htag (string, optional) – Hilbert space tag.

  • maximum (int, optional) – Maximum value for n.

Example¶

>>> n = var("n")
>>> ket_n = Ket(n); bra_n = Bra(n)
>>> a = AnnihilationOperator()
>>> a*ket_n
n**(1/2)|n-1>
>>> bra_n*a
(1 + n)**(1/2)<n+1|
